reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 8, 2024
reviews.reviewText: Good read. The delivery person said he left it on my front porch, but it wasn't there. I thought someone had taken it off my porch or he delivered it to the wrong address. Then I looked at the picture and he left it on the side of my house on the floor of my garage. I could have driven over it. They should say exactly where they deliver a package and leave it in a safe place.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 3, 2024
reviews.reviewText: I enjoyed the history of the story and how Belle’s story was told. I love hearing about all the manuscripts, art and books.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 9, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Best Book Club Read 2023
reviews.reviewText: Not sure why I did not read this, but was a book club selection for January. Great read, SO MUCH history and a woman's story. An absolute must read!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 26, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Captivating, Thought Provoking
reviews.reviewText: History, couched gently in fiction, reveals itself as timeless. The life of Belle da Costa Greene and those whose lives she touched is beautifully explored. More than a biography of a remarkable woman, this book is a portrait of an era when her struggles and achievements have continued to ripple into our world today. The story of Ms. Greene is compelling as the authors pay tribute to her life and legacy. The reader comes away with a heightened awareness of her world and our world where the struggle for equality and dignity continue. It's a story I could not put down and even drew me to the accounts of how the two authors came to collaborate on this project. Highly recommend.

reviews.reviewText: Well written, keeps you interested, gives you a great look at the struggles of a young black women.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 8, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 3.0 out of 5 stars 2.5 stars for story ~ 5 stars for Belle da Costa Greene
reviews.reviewText: I am happy I read this book because it made me aware of Belle da Costa Greene and her accomplishments. She was an amazing woman. After doing my own research and looking further into Ms. da Costa Greene's life, I learned so much more about her than what was written in this fictionalized account of her life. The book did NOT do her justice. I think much of what was written would have embarrassed her. This fictionalized version of her life took great liberties with the truth. As with all fictionalized accounts, the author(s) can only guess what happened and what was said in most instances about which they write if these things were not actually documented.I am an avid reader. My knowledge of slavery, the aftermath for the former slaves/'freed' people, as well as life in our world today is extensive, and I have read widely on these topics.It seems to me that Ms. Christopher Murray, in writing what Belle's mother (Genevieve Ida Fleet) 'felt' - and I quote (end of page 227 in paperback version of book) "She gave up the identity she'd loved to live among people she abhorred, ONLY for the betterment of her children." Really? Ms. Greene's mother ABHORRED Caucasians (all Caucasians?). Obviously, her life was not always an easy one, but she did reap the benefits of her daughter's intelligence, abilities and success (and the largesse of J.P. Morgan). Yes, Ms. da Costa Greene deserved what he gave her, but let's not forget that she was a working WOMAN in the early 1900's, and most bosses would not have remunerated a valued and deserving employee as he had. I doubt Mrs. Fleet loathed him - just one person as an example. So, living among all those Mrs. Fleet despised couldn't have been so awful. Actually, I don't think she despised them at all. Being that this comment was not taken from any diaries or other printed format, it can only be deduced that these are Ms. Christopher Murray's feelings, and not Mrs. Fleet's.The afterword by Ms. Benedict points out how removed she's been and protected by her white privilege. So it is fortunate for her that she collaborated with Ms. Christopher Murray, who showed her how misguided she'd been all her life. It is unfortunate that she chose to mention George Floyd as a victim/hero. Perhaps Ms. Benedict might consider doing some research on the person HE was, a very poor example of what I think she was trying to show.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 20, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Couldn’t Put it Down
reviews.reviewText: This is the most engrossing and compelling book I’ve had the privilege of reading in years. The protagonist, named Belle, has, and will, stay with me for a long time (if not forever). Thank you Marie and Victoria.
Es una historia novelada pero los personajes existieron. Muy entretenida. La lees muy rápido

Excellently written book revealing the racial tension in the early 19th century in the USA and life of talented, ambitious, and smart librarian and art collector. An easy read that allows you to learn about history and art.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on October 29, 2023
reviews.reviewText: We visited the JP Morgan library in New York a few weeks ago. Apparently this book has put it on the map! A wonderful place to visit
